Class StringLists

  • java.lang.Object
    • StringLists

  • public class StringLists
extends java.lang.Object
    In this project you will learn to use the ArrayList class. Some of the problems below are ones that we've seen in the past. Don't just copy/paste from your original solution, solve it again! It's good practice. First you will complete each method using an array. Next you will complete the the same method immediately following the array problem except this time you will use an ArrayList. Here is a quick reference to the Java List methods. E represents any Java object type: int size() returns the number of elements in the List boolean add(E obj) appends obj to end of list; returns true void add(int index, E obj) inserts obj at position index (0 <= index <= size) moving elements at position index and higher to the right (adds 1 to their indices) and adjusts size E get(int index) gets the element at the specified index E set(int index, E obj) replaces the element at position index with obj. returns the element formerly at the specified position E remove(int index) removes element from position index, moving elements at position index + 1 and higher to the left (subtracts 1 from their indices) and adjusts size. Returns the element formerly at the specified position
    Version:
    Unit 6
    Author:
    (Alexander Shapiro)

      Given a List of Strings, return a List with the target String removed No need to create a new list with the String removed, just modify the strings parameter directly WARNING: This can be tricky! If you are using a for loop, what happens when you remove an item based on the current index?

      Given a List of Strings, return the same List except but with the first and the last elements have their exchanged.

      Given an array of Strings, return a NEW copy of the array except that in the new array the first and the last elements have their positions exchanged.

        Returns:

      • removeTarget

        public static java.util.List<java.lang.String> removeTarget(java.util.List<java.lang.String> strings,
                                                            java.lang.String target)
        Given a List of Strings, return a List with the target String removed No need to create a new list with the String removed, just modify the strings parameter directly WARNING: This can be tricky! If you are using a for loop, what happens when you remove an item based on the current index?
        Parameters:
        strings - a List of Strings
        target - the String to remove
        Returns:
        the list with the target String removed

      • removeTarget

                                              java.lang.String target)
        Given an array of Strings, return an array with the target String removed Create a new array to store the new smaller array
        Parameters:
        strings - an array of Strings
        target - the String to remove
        Returns:
        a new array of Strings that has target removed

        Returns:

      • swapFirstLast

        public static java.lang.String[] swapFirstLast(java.lang.String[] strings)

        Parameters:
        strings - an array of Strings
        Returns:
        a new array of Strings that is the same as strings except that the first and last elements are exchanged
